Thank you for the website and I agree with some of the other posters....Hannah is one lucky little girl to have such a wonderful family! God bless you all.
Posts.Title: HELP! 10 year old with bc cjsocal Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2008 07:21PM susiered wrote: Hi Suze I just had to have my right expander removed due to infection. I chose to keep my left expander because I have to do radiation and my radiation oncologist said it would be better to leave it in so we can see how well the skin does. I really want implants, and have no desire to have any of the other forms of reconstruction, so it was a logical choice for me. I just did not want any more very invasive surgeries like the trams. Of course my left breast was healing and  doing great. If it had been red and hard like yours, I would have had it removed. I hope you do well with whatever you decide and I will say a prayer for you! Susan
Posts.Title: URGENT help needed - implant removal. Should I get both out? Suze Suze

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2009 12:07AM susiered wrote: Suze I am so glad it is over and you are doing o.k. I am so sorry you had to lose them, but maybe after a while you will be ready for the diep. I so understand how you feel about it not being the game plan, as it happened to me also. Just take care of yourself, let your body heal, and then make your decisions. My heart goes out to you and you are in my prayers! Susan
Posts.Title: URGENT help needed - implant removal. Should I get both out? Suze Suze

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 06:42AM susiered wrote: Lauralou I know what you mean about kinda "wearing out" our support people. I know I have huge support from so many friends and family, and I think we are ALL just worn out. Everyone is ready for me to be well and get my life back together. I know they are still there and will do whatever I need, but all this is long and hard and it does wear you out.I'm sure all your loved ones are the same, but remember they love you and will be there for you I am sure. But like you said this is a graet place to vent and find encouagement. No matter how tired we are..we have to keep on keepin on. At least you can see some light at the end of the tunnel. I have been wearing prosthesis and while they are definatly not me, they do make me look likea woman again in my clothes and I am so happy I got them until I can have reconstruction. Good luck to you! God Bless! Susan

Posts.Title: Curls - Here to Stay??? jillyG susiered

Posts.Content: susiered wrote: I had no idea where to post this, so I will try here first. I finished 6 rounds of THC in Oct. 08. I continue to do herceptin every three weeks until August. I have battled with low  rbc all the way through chemo. I had 2 blood transfusions during chemo and 1 in December. I went yesterday for my herceptin and the Onc said my hemoglobin is 10.2. That is up from what it was 3 weeks ago. At that time it was 8.9. So it looks like my body is trying to recover, which is good. The thing that concerns me is that my ferritin levels were very elevated. I believe the high end of normal is 160 and mine is 590. My AST liver enzymes were also very slightly elevated- 42..normal is 5-40. Does anyone know anything about this? Especially the high ferritin? I have googled it and it says it can be a sign of many things including cancer in the body. Of course that scared me to death. Could the blood transfusions be the culprit? From what I have read your body does not rid itself of excess iron (ferritin). I asked my Onc if the high levels could be bad and all I got was "yes...we will have to watch it" UUURRRR!!  Dx 5/2/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 2/7 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: high ferritin levels/ susiered Cilla39

Posts.Content: susiered wrote: Hello everyone, I am wondering if there are any ladies out there who have done radiation and have fibromyalgia. I am 14 days into my rads and my fibro is acting up bad. My muscles in my chest and the muscles in my shoulder are twitching, tightening, and hurting very bad. I am afraid to continue with the rads because of what it is doing to my muscles. Is it temporary or permanent. I know rads changes tissues, so I am afraid it is just distroying my muscles. Anyone with fibro knows the pain we deal with this stuff!!. I know I need to be concerned about making sure the cancer doesn't come back and believe me I am. I am also concerned about the quality of life I will have after all this is done. Anyone out there that can help me? Unfortunatly my rads doc is out of town until Thursday, so the office just said to stay home until I can see her. Any info on this would sure be appreciated!! Susan Dx 5/2/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 2/7 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: radiation and fibromyalgia susiered Jknee54

Posts.Content: May 18, 2010 04:40PM susiered wrote: Designermom mine was a little farther along than yours...I was stage IIB, but I like you had a small child. An 8 year old boy I just have to be here to raise. I hit it with everything I could. I had double mast, 6 rounds chemo, 33 rads, and now I'm taking tamoxafen. If it comes back, I can say I did everything I possibly could. I am in no way trying to talk you into something. I would wait until your final path comes in and then see what your onc suggests. It is like you said though, just something to think about......did I do everything I could. Good luck to you sweetie and you will figure out what is best for you. Susan
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2009 05:45PM susiered wrote: Ladies thank you for your responses. It helps to know I am not the only one dealing with the radiation/fibro stuff. I finally got to see my rads oncologist, but all he said was he doesn't know how the rads will affect my fibro long term, but you have to keep going. He did give me a presciption for some pain meds, although they don't seem to help much. Sister I am glad to hear you are starting to feel better. I took your advice and put myself back on my xanex today and it does seem to help. As I am sure you know well, rest is a big factor when it comes to fibro and that is something I have not had much of since I started rads. Just can't seem to sleep. They even gave me a prescription sleep aid, which does not putt to me sleep. What time I do sllep it is not restful. I am sure that is not helping my problems. Barb I am also sorry your questions did not get answered. If I would have seen it I would have. You are so right how noone understands the pain. I have had this since I was a little girl and had test after test run. Noone could figure out what was wrong and finally said it was all in my head. It wasn't until I was 30 yrs old that I was finally diagnosed. I got so tired of being told I was not really hurting. I KNEW how I felt..and it hurt! I did have a flare with my mastectomies and had a very long hard recovery. I was just starting to feel somewhat better when rads started and it started all over again. peeps congratulations on finishing those rads! I know you are excited! I wish you all the best of luck! Susan
Posts.Title: radiation and fibromyalgia susiered Jknee54

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2009 09:26PM susiered wrote: I had this same problem after my bi-lateral mast. I was told it was a combination of the anesthesia trying to get out of my body and the pain pills I took while in the hospital. It was awful for about 2 weeks. It did get better.
Posts.Title: BODY ODOR birenegn ghety

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2008 04:19PM susiered wrote: Fran, at 2 weeks post surgery you should still be dragging. Your body has been through sooo much and at 2 weeks is only beginning to heal. I had double mast on Nov. 13th with expanders and I am STILL dragging. I did get aninfection in my right expander and have to go back in for surgery to have it removed, but even with that I think I still would be tired. Just be kind to yourself, and when you are tired and need a nap...take one. It is your body telling you it needs it so it can heal. I was told by my PS it would be months before I was really feeling good again. Like some of the other ladies said, we all heal at different rates. I had chemo before surgery, so it might take me longer. Just don't beat yourself up....it WILL get better! Susan
Posts.Title: Frustrated With Recovery flb1011 2Hands4me

Posts.Content: susiered wrote: Hi Ladies, This is actually something I should already know since I had surgery back in November. I was reading over my path report and am not sure how to interpret it.I was told before surgery and chemo (I had neo-adjuvent) it was thought I had 2 positive lymph nodes. This is what my path report says after. Left breast tissue axillary sentinal node #1, CPS 1319, biopsy-one out of one lymph node positive for metastatic carcimoma(1.2 cm in size) Left breast, axillary contents, lymph node dissection-one out of seven nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma. My question is....did I have 1 or 2 positive lymph nodes? Is the sentinal node seperate from the lymph node dissection? I am confused. The crazy thing is I know my dr. told me, but for the life of me I can't remember what was said. If any of you can help it would be so appreciated! Thanks, Susan Dx 5/2/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 2/7 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
